title: Week 1: It‚Äôs Alive - Bootstrapping the Simulated Mind
text:
‚ÄúLife, although it may only be an accumulation of anguish, is dear to me, and I will defend it.‚Äù ‚Äî Frankenstein



In our first week, we‚Äôre focusing on building the bare-bones agent scaffold. This includes: - Basic movement capabilities - Environmental observation - Simple action loop - Logging system for debugging



### Agent üßÖ



Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.


AILO-style: A digital being that‚Äôs learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).



### Event Loop üßÖ



Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.


AILO-style: The agent‚Äôs internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.



### Reflex Agent üßÖ



Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.


AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).









Basic terrain setup
Essential game objects
Navigation mesh for agent movement





Movement controller
State machine for idle/move behaviors
Basic collision detection





Event logging
Action tracking
State changes








Input processing
State updates
Action execution





Environmental perception
Decision making
Action execution





Simple stimulus-response patterns
Basic decision making
Immediate action execution





In Week 2, we‚Äôll be adding: - Long-term memory system - Time-stamped events - Memory retrieval strategies



Greetings, Earthling! Let me explain what we built this week in simple terms:
What We Built: A digital being that can move around and react to its environment. Think of it as a very simple robot that can walk and respond to basic commands.
Why It Matters: Before we can build complex AI that thinks and feels, we need to start with the basics. This is like teaching a baby to crawl before it can walk.
How to Explain It to Your Dog: Woof! (Translation: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a new puppy learning to move its legs for the first time. Simple, but necessary!‚Äù)
Stay tuned for more updates as we bring our first agent to life!

title: AILO Glossary
text:
Welcome to the AILO glossary, where we peel back the layers of AI terminology to reveal both the formal definitions and our more approachable AILO-style interpretations.





Formal: An autonomous entity that perceives its environment and takes actions to achieve specific goals.
AILO-style: A digital being that‚Äôs learning to walk before it can run (or think, or feel).








Formal: A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.
AILO-style: The agent‚Äôs internal clock that keeps it from standing still like a statue.








Formal: An agent that selects actions based on the current percept, ignoring the rest of the percept history.
AILO-style: A digital creature that reacts first and asks questions later (or never).








Formal: A structured mental representation about the world held with some confidence.
AILO-style: A hunch the agent will probably act on‚Ä¶ even if it‚Äôs wrong.


This glossary will grow as we add more layers to our simulated minds. Each term marked with üßÖ has both a formal definition and an AILO-style interpretation that makes it more approachable and fun.

title: AILO Blog
text:
Welcome to my blog, a storytelling-engineering journal that explores the strange, emotional, and sometimes unpredictable world of simulated intelligence. This blog documents the design of increasingly complex AI agents ‚Äî not as models in a paper, but as characters in a world. You will hopefully see my successes, but more often you will see my failures.
Each post follows a weekly build cycle with:

title: AILO Blog
text:
Core Goal
To build agents that don‚Äôt just work ‚Äî they remember, feel, and change. This blog tracks that evolution, combining:

Research-inspired engineering
Weekly storytelling
Experimental system design

title: AILO Blog
text:
üìÜ Current Phase

Phase 1: Simulated Mind in a Game World
A 12-week experiment in designing agents that live, reflect, and grow inside a Stardew Valley‚Äìstyle sandbox. Each week introduces a new layer of mind ‚Äî from walking to memory to personality drift.


üó∫Ô∏è Latest Progress
‚úÖ Week 1 ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Alive: Bootstrapping the Simulated Mind‚Äù (Coming Soon) - Building the bare-bones agent scaffold - Movement, observation, and basic loop - Event loop and reflex agents

title: AILO Blog
text:
üßÖ What the Onion Means
Wherever you see this icon ‚Üí üßÖ That marks a layered word: something that needs peeling.
Hover over the onion icon after a word to see its layered meaning!
These terms will have: - The official definition - And my AILOcard-style version ‚Äî honest, funny, and functional
Example: Belief üßÖ


Belief


Formal: A structured mental representation about the world held with some confidence.


AILO-style: A hunch the agent will probably act on‚Ä¶ even if it‚Äôs wrong.



These definitions live in the glossary and appear in hover-tooltips throughout posts.

title: AILO Blog
text:
üëΩ Who Is the Martian?
Back in middle school, my Physics teacher told me the only way to understand something was to pretend you were explaining it to a man from Mars.
I‚Äôve never forgotten that.
At the end of every post you‚Äôll find a Martian Mode üëΩ. This is a plain-language TLDR written for someone from another world ‚Äî or another field.
It breaks down: - What I built - Why it matters - How to explain it to your obtuse martian friend
Because interpretability isn‚Äôt just for the models ‚Äî it‚Äôs for the humans, too.

title: AILO Blog
text:
Future Phases
This isn‚Äôt just a one-off experiment. AILO unfolds across three interconnected phases:









Phase
Title
Focus
üëΩ Simple explanation




Phase 1
Simulated Mind in a Game World
Agents, memory, mood, identity (Unity-based)
How intelligence is made ‚Äî like growing a brain one behavior at a time


Phase 2
LLM Debugger
Visual tooling for understanding how LLMs think
How intelligence thinks ‚Äî and how to actually look inside its head


Phase 3
Quantum-Native Reasoning
Research into quantum-aligned reasoning systems
How intelligence can be redefined ‚Äî with math that doesn‚Äôt follow our rules

title: AILO Blog
text:
Why This Blog Exists
This isn‚Äôt a devlog. It‚Äôs not a textbook. It‚Äôs a research-meets-narrative experiment ‚Äî an engineering novel, one post at a time.
You‚Äôll see code.
You‚Äôll meet characters.
And you‚Äôll slowly forget whether the agent is simulating a mind ‚Äî or you are.
